records.text: Good day everyone!The #HappyDoor backdoor is the focus of today's #readoftheday: The HappyDoor malware has been attributed to APT #Kimsuky, a North Korean group that focuses on espionage and has been active as far back as 2012 and mainly targets the South Korean government [2].According to the AhnLab, Inc. Security Intelligence Cener (ASEC) the malware is commonly spread through phishing emails and contains a compressed file (TA0001 - Initial Access, T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment). Contained within this compressed file exists the scripting file that will ultimately lead to the HappyDoor malware. Multiple living-off-the-land binaries are abused here which include PowerShell (TA0002 - Execution, T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell), Windows Command Shell (T1059.003 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell), Regsrv32.exe (TA0005 - Defense Evasion, T1218.010 - System Binary Proxy Execution: RegSvr32) just to name a few. This is a lot more technical details that can help you improve your security posture and mature your threat hunting process! Enjoy and Happy Hunting!Kimsuky Group's new backdoor appears (HappyDoor)https://asec.ahnlab.com/ko/67128/Intel 471 #CyberSecurity #ITSecurity #InfoSec #BlueTeam #ThreatIntel #ThreatHunting #ThreatDetection #HappyHunting #Intel471

records.text: “A single #bitcoin donation worth almost $740,000 has been made to #JulianAssange’s cause, covering nearly the entirety of the cost of his chartered jet.Supporters of Assange have multiple forums to donate, including directly through cryptocurrency.WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange arrived in Canberra at 7.37pm on Wednesday.#WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange arrived in Canberra at 7.37pm on Wednesday. A transaction recorded on mempool.space – a software website used to visualise data about the Bitcoin ecosystem – shows one user donated ‎8.07173122 BTC to Assange’s link, which converts to $739,789.Assange’s wife, lawyer Stella Assange, told #Reuters on Wednesday that this week’s chartered flights cost $782,334.Assange’s team has also raised $793,456 via #Crowdfunder and $20,384 via #GoFundMe, meaning his campaign has surpassed the cost of the jet hire.”<https://smh.com.au/politics/federal/julian-assange-freed-live-updates-wikileaks-founder-returns-to-australia-20240627-p5jp40.html>

records.text: Good day everyone!The #HappyDoor backdoor is the focus of today's #readoftheday: The HappyDoor malware has been attributed to APT #Kimsuky, a North Korean group that focuses on espionage and has been active as far back as 2012 and mainly targets the South Korean government [2].According to the AhnLab, Inc. Security Intelligence Cener (ASEC) the malware is commonly spread through phishing emails and contains a compressed file (TA0001 - Initial Access, T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment). Contained within this compressed file exists the scripting file that will ultimately lead to the HappyDoor malware. Multiple living-off-the-land binaries are abused here which include PowerShell (TA0002 - Execution, T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell), Windows Command Shell (T1059.003 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell), Regsrv32.exe (TA0005 - Defense Evasion, T1218.010 - System Binary Proxy Execution: RegSvr32) just to name a few. This is a lot more technical details that can help you improve your security posture and mature your threat hunting process! Enjoy and Happy Hunting!Kimsuky Group's new backdoor appears (HappyDoor)https://asec.ahnlab.com/ko/67128/Intel 471 #CyberSecurity #ITSecurity #InfoSec #BlueTeam #ThreatIntel #ThreatHunting #ThreatDetection #HappyHunting #Intel471

records.text: Good day everyone!The #HappyDoor backdoor is the focus of today's #readoftheday: The HappyDoor malware has been attributed to APT #Kimsuky, a North Korean group that focuses on espionage and has been active as far back as 2012 and mainly targets the South Korean government [2].According to the AhnLab, Inc. Security Intelligence Cener (ASEC) the malware is commonly spread through phishing emails and contains a compressed file (TA0001 - Initial Access, T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment). Contained within this compressed file exists the scripting file that will ultimately lead to the HappyDoor malware. Multiple living-off-the-land binaries are abused here which include PowerShell (TA0002 - Execution, T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell), Windows Command Shell (T1059.003 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell), Regsrv32.exe (TA0005 - Defense Evasion, T1218.010 - System Binary Proxy Execution: RegSvr32) just to name a few. This is a lot more technical details that can help you improve your security posture and mature your threat hunting process! Enjoy and Happy Hunting!Kimsuky Group's new backdoor appears (HappyDoor)https://asec.ahnlab.com/ko/67128/Intel 471 #CyberSecurity #ITSecurity #InfoSec #BlueTeam #ThreatIntel #ThreatHunting #ThreatDetection #HappyHunting #Intel471

records.text: Good day everyone!The #HappyDoor backdoor is the focus of today's #readoftheday: The HappyDoor malware has been attributed to APT #Kimsuky, a North Korean group that focuses on espionage and has been active as far back as 2012 and mainly targets the South Korean government [2].According to the AhnLab, Inc. Security Intelligence Cener (ASEC) the malware is commonly spread through phishing emails and contains a compressed file (TA0001 - Initial Access, T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment). Contained within this compressed file exists the scripting file that will ultimately lead to the HappyDoor malware. Multiple living-off-the-land binaries are abused here which include PowerShell (TA0002 - Execution, T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell), Windows Command Shell (T1059.003 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell), Regsrv32.exe (TA0005 - Defense Evasion, T1218.010 - System Binary Proxy Execution: RegSvr32) just to name a few. This is a lot more technical details that can help you improve your security posture and mature your threat hunting process! Enjoy and Happy Hunting!Kimsuky Group's new backdoor appears (HappyDoor)https://asec.ahnlab.com/ko/67128/Intel 471 #CyberSecurity #ITSecurity #InfoSec #BlueTeam #ThreatIntel #ThreatHunting #ThreatDetection #HappyHunting #Intel471
